article.title: Structural Variability from Noisy Tomographic Projections

choices: Two images depicting different molecular structures from a cryo-EM dataset.
Two images depicting the same molecular structure from a cryo-EM dataset, but with different orientations.
Two images depicting similar molecular structures from a cryo-EM dataset, but high noise levels make it difficult to discern the differences.
Two images depicting different stages of sample preparation in a cryo-EM experiment.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 2 illustrate about the sample covariance matrix in high-dimensional regimes?
choices: In both low- and high-dimensional regimes, all eigenvalues are concentrated around the population eigenvalue.
The eigenvalue distribution follows a Marˇcenko-Pastur distribution in both low- and high-dimensional regimes.
In high-dimensional regimes, the spectrum spreads, while in low-dimensional regimes, all eigenvalues are concentrated around the population eigenvalue.
The signal eigenvalue "pops out" only in low-dimensional regimes.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main effect of shrinkage on Bn and Σn, as depicted in Figure 3?
choices: Shrinkage increases the relative error of Bn and Σn at low signal-to-noise ratios.
Shrinkage has a negligible effect on Bn and Σn across all signal-to-noise ratios.
Shrinkage significantly reduces the relative error of Bn and Σn, particularly at low signal-to-noise ratios.
Shrinkage only affects the eigenvectors of Σn, not its eigenvalues.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 4 illustrate about the impact of Contrast Transfer Functions (CTFs) on the least-squares estimators?
choices: The sum of the square magnitudes of CTFs forms a high-pass filter, improving conditioning.
CTFs do not influence the conditioning of least-squares estimators.
The sum of the square magnitudes of CTFs forms a bandpass filter, worsening the conditioning of least-squares estimators.
CTFs only affect the eigenvalues of the estimators, not their eigenvectors.
